text: Praise ye the LORD. O give thanks unto the LORD; for he is good: for his mercy endureth for ever.
text_kjv: Praise ye the LORD. O give thanks unto the LORD; for he is good: for his mercy endureth for ever.
text_niv: Psalm 106Praise the Lord.Give thanks to the Lord, for he is good;his love endures forever.
text_esv: Praise the LORD! Oh give thanks to the LORD, for he is good, for his steadfast love endures forever!
text_nlt: Praise the LORD! Give thanks to the LORD, for he is good!His faithful love endures forever.
text_msg: Hallelujah!Thank God! And why?Because he's good, because his love lasts.
text_nasb: Praise the LORD! Oh give thanks to the LORD, for He is good; For His lovingkindness is everlasting.
context: Psalm 106, the second psalm concluding Book IV of the Psalter (Psalms 90-106), functions as a historical review and confession of Israel's sins. Understanding its opening verse requires appreciating the historical context of the Psalter and the likely circumstances in which it was sung. The Psalter, a collection of hymns and prayers, was compiled over centuries, encompassing experiences from the time of David to the post-exilic period. Book IV often reflects on themes of God's sovereignty amidst national hardship and exile. Psalm 106 specifically recalls the repeated cycles of rebellion and deliverance throughout Israel's history, beginning with the Exodus and continuing through the wilderness wanderings, the conquest, and the period of the judges. The call to praise ('Hallelujah' in Hebrew) and give thanks to the Lord was a common liturgical formula, a staple in temple worship. The phrase 'for his mercy endureth for ever' (Hebrew: *ki le’olam chasdo*) served as a refrain, rhythmically punctuating the historical narrative and providing a counterpoint to the litany of Israel's failures. This refrain suggests a priestly origin or use within established liturgical practices. The psalm, therefore, served as a communal act of repentance and a renewed commitment to faithfulness, sung perhaps during times of national crisis to remind the people of God’s unchanging character despite their repeated transgressions. Knowing this history, the verse takes on deeper meaning, reminding us of the Israelites' repeated transgressions and God's unchanging grace.
meaning: Psalm 106:1 presents a foundational theological truth: God's goodness and enduring mercy (Hebrew: *chesed*). The call to 'Praise ye the LORD' is not merely a command but an invitation to recognize and celebrate God's inherent worthiness. It acknowledges that God is due honor and adoration based on His very nature. The subsequent phrase, 'O give thanks unto the LORD,' emphasizes gratitude as an appropriate response to God's acts and character. Thanksgiving acknowledges that we are recipients of God's blessings and provision. The statement 'for he is good' is a declaration of God's intrinsic moral perfection and benevolence. It asserts that God's actions are consistently motivated by goodness and reflect His righteous character. 'Goodness' in this context encompasses both His moral purity and His active concern for the well-being of His creation. Crucially, the declaration that 'his mercy endureth for ever' forms the core of the verse's theological significance. *Chesed* is often translated as 'mercy,' 'loving-kindness,' 'steadfast love,' or 'unfailing love'. It conveys a covenantal love, a commitment that transcends human merit and persists despite human failures. It is God's persistent, loyal love extended towards His people, even in their rebellion and sin. The repetition of this truth within the Psalm serves to emphasize the unshakeable foundation of God's character amidst the historical narrative of Israel's unfaithfulness. This verse highlights that God's love is not contingent on human performance but is rooted in His own unchanging nature.
application: Psalm 106:1 calls us to a life of praise, thanksgiving, and trust in God's enduring mercy. In our daily lives, we can cultivate a habit of praising God for His goodness, even when facing challenges or difficulties. This involves intentionally acknowledging His presence and sovereignty in all circumstances. We can practice expressing gratitude for the blessings we often take for granted – our health, our relationships, our provision, and the beauty of creation. Keeping a gratitude journal or simply pausing throughout the day to thank God can transform our perspective and cultivate a heart of thankfulness. Recognizing that God 'is good' provides a foundation of hope and confidence in a world often characterized by suffering and injustice. Even when we don't understand God's ways, we can trust that His intentions are ultimately good. This also challenges us to reflect God's goodness in our own actions, striving to live with integrity, compassion, and generosity towards others. The assurance that 'his mercy endureth for ever' offers profound comfort and encouragement, especially when we struggle with our own sin and failures. Knowing that God's love is not dependent on our perfection frees us to confess our shortcomings, seek forgiveness, and experience the transformative power of His grace. This verse can also motivate us to extend mercy and forgiveness to others, recognizing that we too are recipients of God's boundless grace. We should actively choose to show love, empathy, and understanding, mirroring the mercy God has shown us. Therefore, we are called to actively practice these teachings in our daily lives, both in our private thoughts and outward actions.
prayer: Gracious and merciful God, we give you thanks for your unchanging goodness and enduring love. We praise you for being a God of compassion, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love. Forgive us for our times of unthankfulness and for the moments when we forget to acknowledge your presence in our lives. Help us to cultivate a heart of gratitude, recognizing the many blessings you have poured out upon us. Remind us daily of your unwavering mercy, especially when we stumble and fall short of your glory. Fill our hearts with your peace and strengthen us to live in accordance with your will. May your goodness shine through us, that others may see your love and grace reflected in our lives. Thank you, Lord, for your faithful promises and your unending love. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Why does the psalm start with praise when it's about Israel's sins? The praise at the beginning of Psalm 106 sets the tone for acknowledging God's character even amidst acknowledging human failure. It highlights that even in remembering past sins, God's goodness and mercy remain constant and worthy of praise, providing a context for repentance and hope.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse

faqs.answer: What does it mean for God to be 'good'? God's goodness, as used in this verse, encompasses His moral perfection, His active concern for His creation, and His provision. It speaks of God's benevolence toward His people, demonstrated in His loving-kindness and steadfastness in His covenants.
faqs.question: Q2

faqs.answer: How is 'mercy' different from 'grace'? While related, mercy emphasizes God's compassion in withholding deserved punishment, and grace emphasizes God's unmerited favor and gift of salvation. Mercy is God not giving us what we deserve, while grace is God giving us what we don't deserve.
faqs.question: Q3

faqs.answer: Is this verse just for Israel, or does it apply to everyone? While rooted in Israel's historical context, the verse's core truth about God's goodness and enduring mercy applies universally. All who call upon the Lord can experience His grace, irrespective of their background. This promise transcends ethnicity and national boundaries.
faqs.question: Q4

faqs.answer: How do I apply this verse when I'm feeling overwhelmed by problems? Focusing on God's goodness and enduring mercy helps to shift our perspective. Remember that God's love isn't dependent on circumstances. Take time to thank Him for blessings, and trust in His character even amidst challenges.
